oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Belle Boyd
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Carte de visite of Confederate spy Belle Boyd
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Spies; Spying

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Espionage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Isabelle Marie Boyd (1844-1900) was a Confederate spy who operated from her father's hotel in Front Royal, Virginia. In one instance, she provided valuable information to General Stonewall Jackson during his attack on Union troops in Front Royal. She was arrested several times. She made her way to England in 1864 and returned to the U. S. in 1866.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Aunt Lizzie" Aiken
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eliza N. "Aunt Lizzie" Atherton Aiken (1817-1906)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Medical personnel; Nurses

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Medical care
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Born in Auburn, New York, she married Cyrus Aiken in 1837 & they moved to Illinois. She enlisted as a nurse with the Sixth Illinois Cavalry near the beginning of the Civil War. She would later care for Union soldiers at Ovington Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee. She was friends with Mary A. ""Mother"" Sturges.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three women from the Scobey family at the McGavock Confederate Cemetery during the Confederate reunion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Cemeteries; Graves; Tombs & sepulchral monuments
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Confederate cemeteries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The McGavock Confederate Cemetery is the nation's largest private Confederate cemetery. Located on two acres of the Carnton plantation in Franklin, Tennessee, the cemetery is the burial site for 1481 Confederates killed at the Battle of Franklin. Carnton served as a field hospital during the 1864 battle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary A. Mother Sturges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of Mary A. Mother Sturges (sometimes spelled Sturgis) dressed in black and seated in a brocade armchair. She holds a closed copy of Will Carleton's "Farm Ballads" in her hands. The book (perhaps a prop) is closed and title is facing outward toward the camera.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nurses; Women
Sturges, Mary A., 1809-1892; Aiken, Eliza A. Atherton, 1817-1906; United States. Army. Illinois Cavalry Regiment, 6th (1861-1865)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary A. Mother Sturges (sometimes spelled Sturgis) was an Union Army nurse during the Civil War. She enlisted with the 6th Illinois Cavalry and served with Aunt Lizzie Aiken in Memphis, Tennessee, at the Adams Block Hospital. Mary A. Sturges was 51 years old when she enlisted and served for four years. She was mustered out in June of 1865. She received a Union pension. She died in Kansas City, Kansas, December 29, 1892 and is buried in the Oak Grove Cemetery. Her monument was erected by the GAR.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph portrait of Lucy Virginia French bet. p. 438 & 439 in "Women of the South Distinguished in Literature" (1865) by Mary Forrest. She is looking directly ahead with her dark curly hair parted in the middle and framing her face. Her lovely dress has wide 3/4-length sleeves with a great deal of lace flowing out of the sleeves and down to her hands. One simple ring is visible on her right hand and she has on drop earrings. There are flowers pinned to her bodice. She has a somewhat symmetrical face.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Authors
French, L. Virginia (Lucy Virginia), 1825-1881; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Authors; Diarists
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: G. R. Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lucy Virginia Smith French (1825-1881) was born in Accomack County, VA. In 1848, she and her sister moved to Memphis, where they became teachers. While living in Memphis, she began writing for the Louisville Journal under the pen name ""L'Inconnue,"" and in 1852 she became the editor of the Southern Ladies' Book. In 1853, she married Col. John Hopkins French & relocated to McMinnville, Tennessee, where they they had three children, 1 boy and 2 girls. She kept detailed diaries during the Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mrs. Lincoln
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Carte de visite of Mary Todd Lincoln. Image appears very similar to photograph taken of her by Matthew B. Brady in his New York, N.Y. studio in 1861. Her head and left arm are in different positions and the chair has been edited out, but the dress and flowers are the same. Her right arm holding the bouquet is also in the same position. See here: http://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2008680392/
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Presidents' spouses
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Lincoln, Mary Todd, 1818-1882; Presidents' spouses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Anne Todd Lincoln (1818-1882) was from a prominent Kentucky family. She married Abraham Lincoln in 1842. She was so deeply traumatized by the assassination of her husband and the deaths of three of her four sons that she began behaving very erratically. As a result, her oldest son, Robert Todd Lincoln, had her committed for insanity in 1875. She is buried with her husband in the Lincoln Tomb, Oak Ridge Cemetery, Springfield, Illinois.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: James Emerick Nagy, Nashville Public Schools Collection, Addition, 1723-1985

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Harriet Tubman
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph of Harriet Tubman (1820?-1913) from the book "Scenes in the Life of Harriet Tubman" by Sarah H. Bradford.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Spies; Spying; Slaves; Fugitive slaves; Slavery; Suffragists; Activists; Women's suffrage; Civil rights; Abolition movement; Abolitionists; Underground railroad system

Tubman, Harriet, 1820?-1913; Slavery; Fugitive slaves; Antislavery movements -- United States; Women abolitionists; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Espionage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Harriet Tubman was born a slave around 1820 in Dorchester County, MD. She escaped to Philadelphia in 1849. From 1849 to 1860, she returned to the South 19 times and escorted over 300 slaves to freedom. She also became a prominent Abolitionist. During the Civil War, she worked as a nurse, cook, and spy for the Union. After the Civil War, she became actively involved in the women's suffrage movement.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: House on College Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two women and a man standing at the entrance of a house on College Street (3rd Avenue) in Nashville. There is a horse and buggy to the left of the house and a small African American child standing at the gate.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Men; Children; Houses; Carriages & coaches
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nashville was occupied by Union troops shortly after Fort Donelson fell on February 16 , 1862. The city remained occupied throughout the rest of the war. The Battle of Nashville (December 15-16, 1864), was the last in a string of defeats for Confederate general John Bell Hood and his Army of Tennessee and was essentially the last major battle in the Western Theater.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: McGavock Confederate Cemetery at Carnton, in Franklin, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: McGavock Confederate Cemetery located on the grounds of the Carnton Plantation, in Franklin, Tennessee. Interred here are 1,500 Confederate soldiers killed during the Battle of Franklin. The graves are organized by states. Adjacent to the cemetery is the McGavock family cemetery.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cemeteries; Tombs & sepulchral monuments
McGavock Confederate Cemetery (Franklin, Tenn.); McGavock family; Franklin, Battle of, Franklin, Tenn., 1864; McGavock, Caroline E. Winder, 1829-1905; McGavock, John, 1815-1893
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Confederate cemetery located at ""Carnton,"" in Franklin, Tennessee. When John and Carrie McGavock lived in the home in 1864, it served as a field hospital during the Battle of Franklin. After the war, in 1866, the McGavocks set aside two acres of land on the property so that 1,500 Confederate soldiers could be reinterred there. This cemetery is the largest privately held Confederate cemetery in the United States. Soldiers from all Confederate states, except Virginia, are buried in the cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vine Grove Methodist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of front and right side of Vine Grove Methodist Church building in Dayton, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Churches; Spies; Spying

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Espionage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the oldest church in Dayton. During the Civil War, it was used to incarcerate women accused of being spies, sometimes referred to as the ""Rhea County Spartans."" They were held in the church, then transported to Chattanooga where they were released upon their promise to disband and cease activity. The building burned at an unknown date after November 29, 1885, and was replaced. See Bettye J. Broyles' Churches and Schools of Rhea County, Tennessee (F443 .R4 B74) p. 105-106.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Looking Back At Tennessee Photograph Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Carnton Mansion, McGavock residence, in Franklin, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front and left side view of the McGavock family Carnton Plantation residence in Franklin, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mansions; Trees; Dwellings; Architectural elements; Porches
Carnton Mansion (Franklin, Tenn.); Historic buildings -- Tennessee -- Williamson County; McGavock family; McGavock, Randal, 1766-1844; McGavock, John, 1815-1893
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Carnton, built largely in the Greek Revival style, was a profitable, large-scale farming operation established in 1826 by former mayor of Nashville, Randal McGavock. When John and Carrie McGavock lived in the home in 1864 during the Battle of Franklin, it served as the largest field hospital in the area. Following the Battle of Franklin, the bodies of four dead Confederate generals--Patrick Cleburne, John Adams, Otho F. Stahl and Hiram B. Granbury--lay on Carntons back porch for a few hours.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Gallant Rescue of the Fair Spy at Shelbyville, Tenn."
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Line drawing entitled "Gallant Rescue of the Fair Spy at Shelbyville, Tenn." Depicts two Civil War officers on horseback surrounded by soldiers holding bayonets as Pauline Cushman looks on from a balcony above them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Spies; Spying

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Espionage
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Scattergood
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This drawing is taken from (page 337) the book "Life of Pauline Cushman the Celebrated Union Spy and Scout"written by F. L. Sarmiento, Esq in 1865. Pauline Cushman (1833-1897) was an actress and a spy for the Union Army during the Civil War. She was to be hanged in Shelbyville but was rescued by Union forces on June 27, 1863. She was later awarded the rank of Brevet-Major in the Union Army and was commended by President Lincoln for her service to the Union.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mrs. John Jordan Crittenden
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph of Elizabeth Moss Crittenden (1803 or 4-1873). It was made from a portrait photograph taken circa 1855-65 by Matthew Brady.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Married 3 times: Daniel Pinchbeck Wilcox (1821), William H. Ashley (1833), John Jordan Crittenden (1853). She was also Crittenden's third wife. Crittenden was a Senator, Governor of Kentucky, and twice U.S. Attorney General during the Harrison and Fillmore administrations. Two of his sons (from his first marriage) were Confederate general George Crittenden and Union general Thomas Leonidas Crittenden.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mrs. W. A. Cheatham
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lithograph of Adelicia Hayes Franklin Acklen Cheatham (1817-1887)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Plantation owners

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Economic aspects
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Married Isaac Franklin (1839), Joseph Alexander Smith Acklen (1849), and William Archer Cheatham (1867). She and Acklen built Belmont Mansion in Nashville. After he died during the Civil War, the Confederate Army threatened to burn 2,800 bales of Adelicia's cotton; it would have financially ruined her. She transported the cotton to New Orleans and ran the Union blockade. In Liverpool, the cotton reportedly fetched $960,000 in gold. She is buried in Mt. Olivet Cemetery in Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Minute book for the Ladies' Tennessee Hospital Association of Nashville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small handwritten volume containing the constitution, the by-laws, and the minutes of the Tennessee Hospital Association--alternately known as the Ladies' Hospital Association of Nashville, the Ladies' Tennessee Hospital Association, and the Nashville Tennessee Hospital Association. The Association was preparing for the opening of a fourth hospital in Confederate Nashville when the volume comes to an end and Nashville falls to Federal forces.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Women

United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee Hospital Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Formed on August 1, 1861, this Nashville-based association sought to provide aid and assistance to sick and wounded soldiers throughout the Confederacy by taking donations of money and items, sewing soldiers' clothing and necessary items, supplying hospitals and staffing them as nurses, maintaining hospital registers, and raising money through staging events. Mrs. Frances B. Fogg served as the first President; Mrs. Dr. Shelby was the first V.P., and Mrs. William Cooper was the first Secretary.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Women

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nannie E. Haskins (1846-1930) was born in Clarksville, the daughter of E.B. and Tennessee Stark Williamson Haskins. In 1870, she married Henry Philips Williams.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucy Virginia French diary
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: French, L. Virginia (Lucy Virginia), 1825-1881
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lucy Virgina Smith French was the daughter of Mease W. and Elizabeth Parker Smith. She was born on March 16, 1825. She was married, on Jan. 12, 1853, to Col. John Hopkins French. By the time of the 1860 U.S. Census of McMinnville, Warren County, Tennessee, they had three children ages six and under, one boy and two girls. Her profession on the 1860 census is listed as "Poetess, Author." She died on March 31, 1881.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rachel Carter Craighead Diaries, 1855-1911
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Rachel Carter Craighead diaries span the latter half of the nineteenth century and the early twentieth century, and they provide a remarkable look at Nashville life. Topics covered in the diary include descriptions of school life in the 1850s, trips to places such as Mammoth Cave, New York, and Newport, as well as life in occupied Nashville during the Civil War
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; Pittsburg Landing, Battle of, Tenn., 1862; Shiloh, Battle of, Tenn., 1862; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Press coverage
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Craighead, Rachel Carter, 1837- 1924
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Craighead, an affluent Nashville young woman with Confederate sympathies, faced the reality of living in occupied Nashville during the Civil War. Born to prominent Nashville banker Daniel F. Carter and Mary J. Buntin Carter in 1837, Rachel Carter married Nashville lawyer Thomas D. Craighead in 1859, and the couple continued to live with her parents at 6th and Union, along with her younger brother John. Wartime brought the death of her brother at Perryville and numerous arrests of her father in Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence from Nashville Federal Provost Marshal concerning the Tennessee Hospital Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten correspondence from Col. Stanley Matthews, Provost Marshal, to his Headquarters passing along a request for travel passes for Mrs. Cooper and "other Ladies of Nashville" so that they could cross the lines and tend to sick and wounded Confederate soldiers.The letter is found within the minute book of the Tennessee Hospital Association--also known as the Ladies' Hospital Association of Nashville, the Ladies' Tennessee Hospital and Clothing Association, and the Nashville Tennessee Hospital Assoc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars

Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Participation, Female; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- War work; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Medical Care
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Matthews, Stanley, 1824-1889
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. William Cooper had served as the Secretary of the Tennessee Hospital Association, formed August 1, 1861, in Confederate Nashville. This association sought to provide aid to sick and wounded soldiers of Tennessee and throughout the Confederacy. The women had tended to sick soldiers camped at the Nashville fairgrounds, sent members to nurse in Bowling Green, and staffed Nashville hospitals as nurses. Here they seek permission to continue their mission under Federal occupation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Resolution of the Tennessee Hospital Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten resolution of the Tennessee Hospital Association--alternately known as the Ladies' Hospital Association of Nashville, the Ladies' Tennessee Hospital Association, the Nashville Tennessee Hospital Association, and Ladies' Tennessee Hospital and Clothing Association. This resolution is written on the back of one of the organization's printed broadsides listing its officers, board, and shipping and receiving merchants. Page 2/reverse of item 35967.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil wars; Women

Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Women; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Charities; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- War Work
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee Hospital Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Formed August 1, 1861, this Nashville association provided aid to sick and wounded soldiers of Tennessee and the Confederacy. This resolution was unanimously adopted on September 2, 1861, and hints at problems that plagued the association. It faced neglect of procedure, unbridled members, mass resignations, and extensive criticism from the male agent called upon for guidance. The Association and the Soldiers' Relief Society eventually asked for oversight by the Young Men's Christian Association.
